column3: To ruin the effect by adding something superfluous; lit. draw a snake and add feet.
column5: During the Warring States period, several servants were competing for a single jug of wine offered by their master. They decided to have a snake-drawing contest; the first one to finish would get the wine. One servant finished quickly, grabbed the wine, and seeing others still drawing, decided to add feet to his snake. Before he could finish adding the feet, another servant completed his snake and snatched the wine, saying, 'Snakes don't have feet, why did you add them?' This idiom illustrates doing unnecessary things that spoil the original outcome.

column3: To add the finishing touch that brings something to life; lit. paint the dragon, dot the eyes.
column5: Legend has it that a famous painter named Zhang Sengyou painted four dragons on a temple wall but left out their eyes. When asked why, he explained that adding the eyes would bring the dragons to life, and they would fly away. People didn't believe him, so he dotted the eyes on two dragons. Instantly, thunder and lightning filled the sky, the wall cracked, and the two dragons flew away, leaving the ones without eyes behind. This idiom signifies adding the crucial final touch that completes a piece of work.

column3: To mend the sheepfold after the sheep are gone; better late than never, to take action after suffering a loss to prevent future losses.
column5: From a story in the 'Stratagems of the Warring States'. A shepherd lost some sheep because his sheepfold had a hole. His neighbor advised him to fix the hole, but the shepherd thought it was useless since the sheep were already gone. The next day, he lost more sheep. Regretfully, he finally repaired the fold and lost no more sheep. The neighbor commented, '亡羊补牢，未为迟也' (Mending the fold after losing sheep is not too late). This idiom means it's never too late to take corrective action after a mistake or loss.

column3: An old man residing near the frontier lost his horse; refers to a blessing in disguise, how misfortune might turn into good fortune.
column5: This idiom comes from the 'Huainanzi'. An old man living near the border (塞翁) lost his horse (失马). His neighbors consoled him, but he said, 'How do you know this isn't good fortune?' Indeed, the horse returned later with a fine stallion. The neighbors congratulated him, but he said, 'How do you know this isn't bad fortune?' His son loved riding the stallion, fell off, and broke his leg. Neighbors offered sympathy, but the old man again questioned if it wasn't good fortune. Soon after, invaders came, and all able-bodied young men were drafted, most dying in battle. The son, due to his broken leg, stayed home and survived. The full phrase is '塞翁失马，焉知非福' (When the old man lost his horse, how could one know it wasn't a blessing?). This idiom signifies that apparent misfortune can sometimes lead to unexpected good luck.

column3: To give up halfway; to leave something unfinished.
column5: This idiom originates from the 'Book of Rites'. It tells the story of Yue Yangzi, who went away to study. After only a year, he returned home. His wife, who was weaving at her loom, asked why he came back so soon. He replied he missed home. His wife then took a knife and cut the cloth she was weaving, explaining that her weaving, like his studies, required accumulating effort thread by thread. Cutting it halfway rendered all previous work useless. Similarly, giving up studies midway meant wasting time. Ashamed, Yue Yangzi went back to his studies and didn't return until he finished. This idiom means to stop doing something before it is completed.

column5: This idiom originates from historical records ('Han Shu'). column5: This phrase was famously used by the Song Dynasty poet Su Shi (Su Dongpo) to praise the works of the Tang Dynasty painter and poet Wang Wei. Su Shi said of Wang Wei's work, '味摩诘之诗，诗中有画；观摩诘之画，画中有诗' (Savor Mojie's [Wang Wei's courtesy name] poetry, there is painting in his poetry; look at Mojie's painting, there is poetry in his painting). It highlights the integration of visual and literary arts, describing paintings that possess deep artistic conception, mood, and evocative power, much like poetry.

column3: The fox borrows the tiger's fierceness; to bully or intimidate others by relying on the power or authority of someone else.
column5: From 'Stratagems of the Warring States'. A tiger caught a fox. The fox claimed the Emperor of Heaven had appointed him king of beasts and dared the tiger to test this. 'Walk behind me,' said the fox, 'and see if any animal doesn't flee.' The tiger agreed. As they walked, all animals fled in terror. The tiger, unaware they feared him and not the fox, believed the fox's bluff. This idiom describes someone who uses the authority of others (假虎威 - borrows the tiger's power) to bully or impress, while having no real power themselves.

Originally used to describe the enjoyment of tasty food, it's now broadly applied to reading, listening, talking, or engaging in any activity with great pleasure and absorption.

column3: So beautiful that fish sink and geese fall; describes exceptional female beauty that captivates all creatures.
column5: This idiom combines two stories about legendary beauties. '沉鱼' (sinking fish) refers to Xi Shi of the Spring and Autumn period. When she washed yarn by the river, fish were so dazzled by her beauty they forgot to swim and sank. '落雁' (falling geese) refers to Wang Zhaojun of the Han Dynasty. When she was sent to marry the Xiongnu chieftain, she played the pipa on horseback. Passing geese heard her sorrowful music and saw her beauty, forgot to flap their wings, and fell from the sky. Together, '沉鱼落雁' (often paired with '闭月羞花' - bì yuè xiū huā, meaning eclipsing the moon and shaming flowers) describes breathtaking female beauty.

column3: To deliberately distort facts or misrepresent the truth; lit. point at a deer and call it a horse.
column5: This idiom originates from the 'Records of the Grand Historian'. During the Qin Dynasty, the powerful eunuch Zhao Gao wanted to test his authority and identify dissenters. He presented a deer to Emperor Qin Er Shi but called it a horse. The emperor, puzzled, asked his officials. Some remained silent, some agreed with Zhao Gao out of fear, and some truthfully said it was a deer. Zhao Gao secretly had those who identified it as a deer punished or executed. This act demonstrated his power to manipulate truth and control the court through intimidation.

column3: To neglect sleep and forget to eat; describes being completely engrossed or absorbed in work or study.
column5: This idiom has roots in several historical texts describing dedicated individuals. For instance, Confucius was described as someone who, in his pursuit of knowledge and teaching, would '发愤忘食，乐以忘忧' (fāfèn wàng shí, lè yǐ wàng yōu - work hard forgetting to eat, be happy forgetting worries). Another source mentions Emperor Yao working so diligently he neglected meals and rest. '废寝' (fèi qǐn) means to forgo sleep, and '忘食' (wàng shí) means to forget food. It vividly portrays intense concentration and dedication to a task, to the point of ignoring basic needs.

column3: With great care; cautiously and attentively.
column5: This idiom originates from the 'Book of Songs' (Shijing). A line describes someone moving cautiously: '维此良人，小心翼翼' (Wéi cǐ liángrén, xiǎoxīn yìyì), praising a good person for being meticulous and careful. '小心' (xiǎoxīn) means careful or cautious, and '翼翼' (yìyì) conveys a sense of reverence, caution, and meticulousness, like the careful folding of wings. It describes someone acting with extreme caution and attentiveness, often due to fear, respect, or the delicate nature of the task.

column3: To play the qin (a stringed instrument) to a cow; to address the wrong audience, to talk to someone who cannot understand or appreciate the subject.
column5: This idiom comes from a story about Gong Mingyi, a musician from the state of Lu during the Spring and Autumn period. He was skilled at playing the qin. One day, seeing a cow grazing peacefully, he decided to play his finest music for it. He played elegant, complex melodies, but the cow ignored him and continued chewing cud. He then played sounds imitating mosquitoes buzzing and calves mooing. The cow immediately looked up, swished its tail, and listened intently. The story illustrates that communication must be tailored to the audience; addressing someone in a way they cannot comprehend is futile, like playing sophisticated music for a cow.

column3: A frog at the bottom of a well; describes a person with a very limited outlook and understanding, unaware of the world outside their narrow experience.
column5: This idiom comes from the philosophical text 'Zhuangzi'. A frog living in a shallow well (井底之蛙) encountered a turtle from the East Sea. The frog bragged about its happy life in the well, claiming it was the master of the water and enjoyed immense freedom hopping around. It invited the turtle in. The turtle tried, but its foot got stuck before it could even get its body in. The turtle then described the vastness of the East Sea, immeasurable by distance or time, making the frog realize its own tiny world and limited perspective. It signifies narrow-mindedness and ignorance due to limited exposure.

column3: In a mess; chaotic, disorderly, confused.
column5: This idiom doesn't have a single origin story but evolved descriptively. '乱' (luàn) means messy or chaotic. '七' (qī, seven) and '八' (bā, eight) are often used in Chinese idioms to signify multiplicity, disorder, or random distribution (like in '七嘴八舌' - qī zuǐ bā shé, meaning 'everyone talking at once'). '糟' (zāo) means rotten, spoiled, or in a bad state. Put together, '乱七八糟' vividly paints a picture of extreme disorderliness, confusion, or a complete mess, applied to both physical spaces and abstract situations.

column3: One hair from nine oxen; describes something extremely insignificant, negligible, or a tiny part of a vast whole.
column5: This idiom comes from a letter written by the famous Han Dynasty historian Sima Qian to his friend Ren An ('Bao Ren An Shu'). Sima Qian had suffered castration as punishment for defending a defeated general. In the letter, he expressed his deep sense of humiliation and despair. He wrote that even if he were executed, his death would be utterly insignificant, like 'one hair from nine oxen' (九牛之一毛), making no difference to the world compared to the loss felt when an ant dies. It emphasizes extreme smallness or insignificance in comparison to a large quantity.

column3: To raise one corner and infer the other three; to deduce many things from one example, to learn by analogy.
column5: This idiom originates from the 'Analects of Confucius'. Confucius described his teaching method and expectations for his students: '不愤不启，不悱不发。举一隅不以三隅反，则不复也。' (Bù fèn bù qǐ, bù fěi bù fā. Jǔ yī yú bù yǐ sān yú fǎn, zé bù fù yě.) This translates to 'I do not enlighten those who are not eager to learn, nor arouse those who are not anxious to give an explanation themselves. If I have presented one corner of a subject and they cannot deduce the other three, I do not repeat the lesson.' '举一隅' (jǔ yī yú) means 'raise one corner,' and '以三隅反' (yǐ sān yú fǎn) means 'infer the other three corners.' It emphasizes the ability to think independently, draw inferences, and apply knowledge flexibly.

column3: Inconceivable; unimaginable, unbelievable, miraculous.
column5: This term originates from Buddhist scriptures, often used to describe the profound and mystical nature of Buddhist doctrines, enlightenment, or the power of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, which are beyond ordinary comprehension or logical reasoning. '不可' (bù kě) means 'cannot,' '思' (sī) means 'think' or 'conceive,' and '议' (yì) means 'discuss' or 'fathom.' Thus, '不可思议' literally means 'cannot be conceived or fathomed.' It's now commonly used to describe anything extremely surprising, amazing, or hard to believe.

column3: To draw a tiger and make it look like a dog; To attempt something ambitious but fail miserably, resulting in a poor imitation.
column5: Originates from the 'Book of Later Han'. Ma Yuan, a general, warned his nephews against imitating two local heroes. He said trying to imitate the admirable Long Boru but failing would still result in being a respectable person ('刻鹄不成尚类鹜' - carving a swan but failing still resembles a duck). But trying to imitate the flamboyant Du Jiliang and failing would result in becoming a frivolous person ('画虎不成反类狗/犬' - drawing a tiger but failing results in resembling a dog). It warns against poor imitation, especially of something grand.

column3: Constant dripping wears away the stone; Persistence prevails.
column5: Originates from the 'Book of Han'. A minor official named Zhang Gui was found stealing a single coin from the treasury daily. column3: Mistaking the reflection of a bow in the cup for a snake; Extremely suspicious, imaginary fears.
column5: This idiom comes from a story in the 'Jin Shu' (Book of Jin). Yue Guang invited a friend for drinks. The friend saw what looked like a snake in his cup (actually the reflection of a bow hanging on the wall) and felt ill afterwards, believing he had swallowed it. Yue Guang later invited him again, showed him the reflection of the bow in the cup, and explained the illusion. The friend immediately recovered. It illustrates how unfounded suspicion and fear can create problems.

column3: To quench one's thirst by thinking of plums; Console oneself with illusions.
column5: From 'A New Account of the Tales of the World'. During the Three Kingdoms period, the famous warlord Cao Cao was leading his troops on a long march under the hot sun. The soldiers were extremely thirsty and morale was low. Cao Cao, knowing there was no water nearby, cleverly pointed ahead and said, 'Ahead of us is a large grove of plum trees, heavy with fruit, sweet and sour, which can quench your thirst!' Hearing this, the soldiers imagined the taste of the plums, their mouths watered, and they temporarily forgot their thirst, regaining the energy to continue marching until they found water. It describes using fantasy or imagination to comfort oneself when needs cannot be met.

column3: To throw a brick to attract jade; To offer a modest opinion/work to elicit better ones from others.

Hoping to inspire Chang Jian to complete the poem with brilliant verses, Zhao Gu deliberately wrote mediocre lines ('抛砖' - throwing a brick) to '引玉' (attract jade - Chang Jian's superior verses). Chang Jian indeed added two magnificent lines. It's used humbly when presenting one's own ideas, hoping they will inspire better contributions from others.

column3: How can this be so?; Outrageous; Absurd.
column5: This is an expression of indignation or disbelief at something considered utterly unreasonable or absurd. '岂' (qǐ) is an interrogative particle meaning 'how could...?', '有' (yǒu) means 'to have' or 'to exist', '此' (cǐ) means 'this', and '理' (lǐ) means 'reason' or 'principle'. Thus, it literally translates to 'How could there be such a reason/principle?'. It's used rhetorically to express strong disagreement or shock at something deemed illogical or outrageous. It appears in various classical texts expressing similar sentiments.

column3: To wait by a stump for a rabbit; To wait idly for opportunities relying on luck.
column5: From the writings of Han Feizi. A farmer in the state of Song was tilling his field when a rabbit, running frantically, collided with a tree stump ('株', zhū), broke its neck, and died. The farmer was delighted, picked up the rabbit, and decided to abandon his farming. He then spent all day waiting ('守', shǒu) by the stump ('待', dài), hoping another rabbit ('兔', tù) would do the same. He never caught another rabbit and became a laughingstock. It criticizes relying on sheer luck and past success without putting in effort.

Legend says someone claimed dates were good for the spleen but bad for the teeth. Another person then decided to swallow them whole to get the benefit without the harm, missing the point entirely. It criticizes superficial learning.

column3: Lord Ye's love of dragons; Professed love for something one actually fears.
column5: From Liu Xiang's 'Xin Xu'. There was a nobleman called Lord Ye (叶公) who professed an extreme fondness ('好', hào) for dragons ('龙', lóng). He decorated his entire house with dragon carvings and paintings. A real dragon heard of his obsession and decided to visit him. When the dragon poked its head through the window, Lord Ye was terrified and fled. This story mocks those who claim to like something but are afraid when confronted with the real thing; it highlights hypocrisy or shallow affinity.

It emphasizes the exhaustive effort and resourcefulness employed to find a solution or accomplish something, often when facing difficulties. It's a descriptive phrase rather than originating from a specific story.

column3: To gain the upper hand by striking first; Preemptive strike.
column5: Originates from historical records like the 'Han Shu' (Book of Han). It refers to taking the initiative ('先发', xiān fā - strike first) to control or subdue ('制', zhì) the opponent ('人', rén). It's a strategic principle, common in military contexts (like Sun Tzu's concepts) but applicable elsewhere, emphasizing the advantage gained by acting before the adversary does, thereby disrupting their plans and seizing control of the situation.

column3: To shoot two hawks with one arrow; To kill two birds with one stone.

It's a very common motif in traditional Chinese art and celebrations, especially weddings.

column3: To make further progress even after achieving a high level; strive for continuous improvement.
column5: Originates from Chan Buddhist texts, particularly the 'Transmission of the Lamp' (景德传灯录). It uses the metaphor of reaching the top of a hundred-foot pole (百尺竿头) to represent achieving great success or enlightenment. The phrase emphasizes that even at this peak, one must strive to take 'one more step' (更进一步) to attain ultimate perfection or understanding, encouraging continuous effort beyond current achievements.

column2: huà hǔ bù chéng fǎn lèi gǒu
column3: To try to imitate something admirable but fail, resulting in an inferior or ridiculous outcome.
column5: This idiom comes from the 'Book of the Later Han' (后汉书), in a letter from the general Ma Yuan (马援) to his nephews. He warned them against blindly imitating role models without understanding their essence. He stated that attempting to emulate a hero without righteousness or a scrupulous man without prudence would lead to poor results. He concluded, 'If you carve a swan and fail, it may still resemble a duck. But if you try to draw a tiger and fail, it will end up looking like a dog.' (刻鹄不成尚类鹜，画虎不成反类狗). It signifies that aiming too high without the requisite skill or substance can lead to failure and ridicule.

column3: A loss may turn out to be a gain; a blessing in disguise. Misfortune might actually be good fortune.
column5: From the 'Huainanzi' (淮南子), this tells of an old man (翁) on the frontier (塞) whose horse ran away (失马). Neighbors offered sympathy, but he asked, 'How do you know this isn't a blessing?' (焉知非福). Later, the horse returned with more fine horses. Neighbors congratulated him, but he questioned if it wasn't misfortune. His son broke his leg riding a new horse. Neighbors commiserated, but the old man again questioned the outcome. Soon after, young men were conscripted for war, and most died. His son, being injured, was spared. The story illustrates that fortune and misfortune are intertwined, and apparent setbacks can lead to unexpected benefits.
